SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. He attributes this to the change in seasons and recent construction projects at his home. These symptoms have been present for about five weeks. The patient has been adhering to his medications but has struggled with his diet due to the construction in his kitchen, leading to more frequent eating out and less healthy food choices. He denies fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. He endorses shortness of breath during exertion and occasional chest cramps that resolve within an hour. He also reports a slight cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fevers, chills. Positive fatigue.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses shortness of breath during exertion and occasional chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Positive cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Positive bloating.
• Neurological: Positive lightheadedness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: In no apparent distress.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive Heart Failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Patient to weigh himself daily and report any weight gain or worsening shortness of breath. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure appears to be well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder yesterday and had a stumble, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a nose job. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial portion of the knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with flexion and valgus stressing of the leg. Normal sensation in the lower extremity. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the left knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment appears normal.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for reevaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, which were too heavy. This happened on Saturday morning. He heard a pop and had to lie down for about an hour before the pain was relieved. He has had stiffness in his lower back since then. He has taken Tylenol, ibuprofen, and used icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and not having the best diet recently. He plans to improve his eating habits.

Regarding his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is taking his medication.

Regarding his osteoarthritis, it gets aggravated occasionally, but it has been manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever, chills, nausea, or vomiting.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses back pain. Denies chest pain.
• Neurological: Endorses tingling in toes on the right foot, resolved.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation at the lumbar spine. Decreased range of motion with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

X-ray lumbar spine is unremarkable with good bony alignment.

Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

Blood pressure readings are slightly elevated.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Acute lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening the area.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: His recent hemoglobin A1c was 8, indicating the need for better control.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.
• Additional Testing: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are slightly elevated.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee pain well and no further workup is needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy. He presents for his annual exam.

Regarding his depression, he has been taking Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He states that his depression is well-managed.

Regarding his hypertension, he is on Norvasc and admits to occasionally forgetting to take it on weekends. However, his blood pressure has been improving.

Regarding his prior lobectomy, he reports no significant issues with shortness of breath, except during high pollen levels and humidity.

He endorses nasal congestion due to pollen and occasional shortness of breath with exertion during his morning runs.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion.
• Respiratory: Occasional shortness of breath with exertion.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Head and Neck: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Well-managed with Prozac.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to continue current management strategies.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: No significant issues with shortness of breath, chest X-ray normal.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure improving, occasional noncompliance with medication.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged to maintain medication compliance, especially on weekends.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right index finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing accident. She reports that her finger was bent back while skiing over moguls four days ago.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation, appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right index finger obtained on today's visit show no fractures and everything lines up well.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. If the pain does not improve, the patient is advised to call and return for a follow-up. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a past medical history significant for iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13. She presents today after being unable to donate blood in December 2019 due to her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverishness with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also notes increased sensitivity to cold and worsening anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue, feverishness, and chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Endorses headaches.
• Psychiatric: Endorses worsening anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Normal physical exam without any significant findings.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a past medical history significant for iron deficiency anemia, who presents today for evaluation and management.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has been dealing with anemia since the age of 13. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: We will recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate after 12 weeks of continued iron supplementation with vitamin C found in orange juice.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Diagnostic Procedures: We will schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If these tests are inconclusive, we will consider a capsule endoscopy.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention. Mr. Ward initially presented to his primary care provider on 3/1/21 with complaints of worsening headaches over the past few months. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size, and no other abnormalities are noted.

The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, described as a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago and worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other symptoms, such as feeling sick, fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he has noticed recently bumping into door frames.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Unremarkable.

Social
Computer programmer, married for 25 years, recently bought a small house. No history of alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use.

FAMILY HISTORY

Adopted, unknown family medical history.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN

1. Refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
2. Schedule surgery for transsphenoidal approach to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
3. Counsel the patient on the risks associated with surgery and anesthesia.
4. Monitor the patient's vision post-surgery for improvement.

The patient is advised to call if they have any questions or concerns.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female who presents with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She reports having chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. The patient has not experienced any chest pain since then. She also had difficulty swallowing during the episode, which has also resolved. The patient denies any recent heartburn or indigestion. She has a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She denies any family history of GI problems.

Physical Examination:
Abdomen
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower belly.

RESULTS

ER visit in October 2020:
• EKG and blood tests were normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female who presents with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She experienced chest pain and difficulty swallowing in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. The patient has not experienced any chest pain or difficulty swallowing since then. The ER visit ruled out any cardiac issues. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient reported going through a stressful job transition during the time of the episode, which may have contributed to her symptoms.

The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. If needed, an EGD will be scheduled to further investigate her esophagus and stomach. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Concerns regarding kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, who presents today for evaluation of her kidney function. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, weighing 4 pounds 8 ounces. She has a history of feeding difficulties, gastroesophageal reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned potential kidney anomalies associated with her syndrome.

The patient's mother reports that Katherine has approximately 8 to 10 wet diapers per day and drinks a good amount of fluids, including water and pea protein milk. She has no known family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Well-nourished, slightly fussy during examination.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Not assessed.
• Cardiovascular: Not assessed.
• Respiratory: Not assessed.
• Gastrointestinal: History of gastroesophageal reflux and feeding difficulties.
• Genitourinary: 8 to 10 wet diapers per day.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of lower extremities and arms.
• Neurological: Developmental delays.
• Integumentary: Not assessed.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Not assessed.
• Cardiovascular: Not assessed.
• Respiratory: Not assessed.
• Gastrointestinal: Not assessed.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of lower extremities and arms.
• Neurological: Not assessed.
• Integumentary: Not assessed.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature for patients with this syndrome.

• Medical Reasoning: To assess for potential kidney anomalies, a kidney ultrasound will be performed.
• Additional Testing: Kidney ultrasound to be completed today.
• Follow-up: If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology is needed. If abnormalities are found, the patient will be scheduled for a follow-up appointment at the town center location to determine next steps and future management.

Patient Agreements: The patient's mother understands and agrees with the recommended medical evaluation plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her arms outstretched. The patient reports severe pain in her right wrist, rating it as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ACE wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The patient denies any previous injuries to her right arm.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Mild tingling in fingers, no numbness.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
RR: 20
Temp: 97.2°F
SPO2: Not reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head/Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
CV: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema.
Right Wrist: Obvious swelling and ecchymosis, tenderness on palpation throughout, pain on flexion, extension, radial deviation, and ulnar deviation, able to make a fist but not tightly, bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have discussed with the patient her current symptoms and diagnosis. I have explained to her that she has a Colles' fracture and will require treatment. The initial treatment plan includes:

1. Applying a brace to her right wrist for support and immobilization.
2. Scheduling surgery to repair the fracture.
3. Prescribing 50 mg of Ultram every 6 hours for pain management.
4. Recommending physical therapy post-surgery to regain strength and function in her wrist.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will wear the brace for approximately 6 weeks and attend physical therapy as recommended. She will return for a follow-up appointment in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans. If her pain does not improve or worsens, she will contact the office.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports working on his property when the injury occurred.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chest pain, and shortness of breath.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and swelling.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: not provided
Respiration: not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain with flexion and extension. Pain to palpation on the medial aspect of the knee. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed. No fractures or bony abnormalities were found.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient reports a fall and twisting of the knee, resulting in pain and swelling.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and inflammation. Provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Advise the patient to elevate and rest the leg, avoiding strenuous activities.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient has a history of hypertension and is currently on 20 mg of lisinopril. Blood pressure was elevated at 150/70 mmHg during the visit.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Refer the patient to a nutritionist to help improve diet and potentially reduce the need for medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that the pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is accompanied by a sensation of the knee giving out. The pain is located internally and involves the whole kneecap. The patient denies hearing or feeling a pop and has no history of injury to the left knee. The pain is not severe enough to require medication and resolves quickly. The patient is concerned about the instability affecting her ability to participate in activities such as line dancing during an upcoming trip.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left knee pain and instability. Denies right knee pain.

Cardiovascular: Reports controlled blood pressure with medication.

Endocrine: Reports slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.

Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.

MSK: Examination of the left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain and instability, likely due to arthritis.
2. Hypertension, controlled with medication.
3. Diabetes mellitus, with slightly elevated morning blood sugars.

PLAN

1. For the left knee pain and instability, prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider initiating physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. Order a hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes management and potential adjustments to Metformin dosage. Encourage the patient to continue monitoring blood sugars and taking medications as prescribed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Cough and sore throat.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer. She is currently undergoing neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. Biopsy of a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports good support from family, friends, and nursing staff.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fatigue.
Respiratory: Reports a dry cough and no shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Reports sore throat and decreased appetite, but no difficulty swallowing.
Psychiatric: Patient reports feeling emotionally and mentally strong.

VITALS

Oxygen saturation: Within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck
- Examination: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.

Skin
- Examination: Erythema on the anterior side of the left chest, possibly related to radiation.

Lower Extremities
- Examination: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Non-small cell lung cancer.
- Medical Treatment: Continue current chemotherapy regimen of cisplatin and etoposide. Continue current dose of radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor size for potential surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow, to be used four times a day to help with eating and drinking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports recent international travel to Zambia. Patient's family owns a donut shop.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and is on metformin.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal tenderness or diarrhea.

VITALS

Weight, heart rate, and temperature within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

LAB RESULTS

Low immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab results are consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report frequent infections or other concerning symptoms.
- Additional Testing: Order blood work to check other antibody levels to rule out other immunodeficiencies.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the nature of IgA deficiency and advised the patient to monitor for any infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract. Instructed the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended assessment and plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. He has been experiencing the pain for approximately 4 days. The patient reports that the pain began after engaging in pottery and ceramics activities during the pandemic. The pain is localized to the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. He rates the pain as a 6 out of 10 and states that it interferes with his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has been engaging in pottery and ceramics activities during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Pulses are equal in all extremities.
NEURO: Sensation is normal to light touch distally.
MSK: 
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. No pain with supination. Pain with pronation. Pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Medial epicondylitis of the right elbow.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The patient is advised to rest the affected arm and wear a sling while awake. He is also instructed to apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for a full week. The patient is advised to refrain from pottery work for the next couple of weeks. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for one week to assess progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up after a fall and chest pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain, thought to be heartburn.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during exertion.
Genitourinary: No complaints.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, abnormal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting sodium intake. Advised to monitor weight daily and contact me if they gain 3 pounds in 2 days.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding diet.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed dietary modifications.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and groin. The pain is intermittent and comes in waves. He reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father). He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief. He experiences nausea but no vomiting.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Abdominal: Reports right-sided abdominal pain and burning sensation during urination.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. Patient may continue to take Tylenol for breakthrough pain.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to use when urinating to catch the stone for further analysis.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel (BMP), urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1 to 2 weeks to check on progress. If symptoms have not improved, discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient is advised to contact the doctor if symptoms worsen or if there are any concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for approximately 6 weeks, which he first noticed after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The patient describes the ulcer as having a foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened edges. He has been on antibiotics for 6 days, with 2-3 days remaining in the course. He has experienced a fever of 99.7 and chills. The patient also reports calf muscle cramping and a red streak along the inside portion of his calf muscle. He has been experiencing difficulty catching his breath and coughing for the past two days.

His blood sugar has been trending in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks, with one spike at 500-600. His last hemoglobin A1c was 6.7.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Fever of 99.7 and chills.
Respiratory: Coughing and difficulty catching breath.
Skin: Non-healing right foot ulcer with foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened edges.
Musculoskeletal: Calf muscle cramping and red streak along the inside portion of the calf muscle.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure: Not provided
Heart rate: Not provided

PHYSICAL EXAM

Foot: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on the heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and odor. No bony exposure.
Vascular: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
2. Diabetes with recent blood sugar instability
3. Possible cellulitis

PLAN

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor redness and swelling in the calf closely.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Recommend the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist for diabetes management.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee with associated pain and erythema.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and yard work. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been causing burning pain and annoyance. He denies fever or chills but reports feeling generally unwell and having a headache since the tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Controlled with lisinopril 20 mg daily.
Diabetes: Controlled with metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain and typical arthritic pain.
Neurological: Denies dizziness or shortness of breath.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Respiration: Normal
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite with possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a tick bite on the right knee, associated pain, erythema, and bull's-eye rash, raising concern for Lyme disease.
- Diagnostic Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm the diagnosis.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks.

2. Hypertension.
- Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
- Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
- Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed and after receiving test results.
